title.narrative: IDP Emergency Health And Nutrition Response In South Sudan - Phase III

description.narrative:
Over 1.2M persons have remained internally displaced and dependent on humanitarian assistance for health and nutritional services since the current conflict commenced in December 2013. As thus, IMA is operating mobile clinics in Upper Nile State which serve IDP populations from Malakal, Panyikang, Melut, Manyo, and Fashoda Counties on the western side of the White Nile River, where the IDP population has increased due to renewed conflict in 2015 and health services are not readily available. The project supports primary health care services, both prevention and treatment, provided through mobile clinics to IDPs and returnee populations as they reintegrate into local communities, with an emphasis on vulnerable people.
Along with partners Coordination of Organizations for Voluntary Service (COSV), Nile Hope Development Forum (NHDF), and the John Dau Foundation (JDF), IMA provides nutrition services in the IDP sites. The project goal is to improve the nutritional status of the population, with an emphasis on vulnerable people and a focus on prevention, screening, and treatment.
